message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Credibility assessment of in silico clinical trials for medical devices
Paper Abstract: In silico clinical trials (ISCTs) are an emerging method in modeling and simulation where medical interventions are evaluated using computational models of patients. ISCTs have the potential to provide cost-effective, time-efficient, and ethically favorable alternatives for evaluating the safety and effectiveness of medical devices. However, ensuring the credibility of ISCT results is a significant challenge. This paper aims to identify unique considerations for assessing the credibility of ISCTs and proposes an ISCT credibility assessment workflow based on recently published model assessment frameworks. First, we review various ISCTs described in the literature, carefully selected to showcase the range of methodological options available. These studies cover a wide variety of devices, reasons for conducting ISCTs, patient model generation approaches including subject-specific versus ‘synthetic’ virtual patients, complexity levels of devices and patient models, incorporation of clinician or clinical outcome models, and methods for integrating ISCT results with real-world clinical trials. We next discuss how verification, validation, and uncertainty quantification apply to ISCTs, considering the range of ISCT approaches identified. Based on our analysis, we then present a hierarchical workflow for assessing ISCT credibility, using a general credibility assessment framework recently published by the FDA’s Center for Devices and Radiological Health. Overall, this work aims to promote standardization in ISCTs and contribute to the wider adoption and acceptance of ISCTs as a reliable tool for evaluating medical devices.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

I've performed a web search for "computer simulation." Here are the key findings:

## Definition and Purpose

Computer simulation is the running of a mathematical model on a computer, the model being designed to represent the behaviour of, or the outcome of, a real-world or physical system.(no content)By changing variables in the simulation, predictions may be made about the behaviour of the system.

## Applications

Computer simulations have become a useful tool for the mathematical modeling of many natural systems in physics (computational physics), astrophysics, climatology, chemistry, biology and manufacturing, as well as human systems in economics, psychology, social science, health care and engineering.

## Historical Background

Computer simulation developed hand-in-hand with the rapid growth of the computer, following its first large-scale deployment during the Manhattan Project in World War II to model the process of nuclear detonation.

## Benefits

It can be used to explore and gain new insights into new technology and to estimate the performance of systems too complex for analytical solutions.

## Types of Simulations

Different types of computer simulations exist, such as continuous dynamic simulations that perform numerical solution of differential-algebraic equations or differential equations, with applications including flight simulators, construction and management simulation games, chemical process modeling, and simulations of electrical circuits.

I've performed a web search for "computer simulation." Here are the key findings:

## Definition and Purpose

Computer simulation is the running of a mathematical model on a computer, the model being designed to represent the behaviour of, or the outcome of, a real-world or physical system.(no content)By changing variables in the simulation, predictions may be made about the behaviour of the system.

## Applications

Computer simulations have become a useful tool for the mathematical modeling of many natural systems in physics (computational physics), astrophysics, climatology, chemistry, biology and manufacturing, as well as human systems in economics, psychology, social science, health care and engineering.

## Historical Background

Computer simulation developed hand-in-hand with the rapid growth of the computer, following its first large-scale deployment during the Manhattan Project in World War II to model the process of nuclear detonation.

## Benefits

It can be used to explore and gain new insights into new technology and to estimate the performance of systems too complex for analytical solutions.

## Types of Simulations

Different types of computer simulations exist, such as continuous dynamic simulations that perform numerical solution of differential-algebraic equations or differential equations, with applications including flight simulators, construction and management simulation games, chemical process modeling, and simulations of electrical circuits.

Links: [{"title":"Uncertainty quantification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uncertainty_quantification"},{"title":"Quantification of margins and uncertainties - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantification_of_margins_and_uncertainties"},{"title":"Talk:Uncertainty quantification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Uncertainty_quantification"},{"title":"Uncertainty analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uncertainty_analysis"},{"title":"Talk:Numerical methods for partial differential equations - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Numerical_partial_differential_equations"},{"title":"Wikipedia:WikiProject Climate change/Figures - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:WikiProject_Climate_change/Figures"},{"title":"Talk:Info-gap decision theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Info-gap_decision_theory"},{"title":"Oil and gas reserves and resource quantification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Contingent_resources"},{"title":"Integrated Carbon Observation System - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Integrated_Carbon_Observation_System"}]

## Uncertainty Quantification

Uncertainty quantification (UQ) is the science of quantitative characterization and estimation of uncertainties in both computational and real world applications.(no content)It tries to determine how likely certain outcomes are if some aspects of the system are not exactly known.

### Key Concepts

Aleatoric and epistemic uncertainty can occur simultaneously in a single term, and uncertainty quantification intends to explicitly express both types of uncertainty separately.

### Main Problem Areas

There are two major types of problems in uncertainty quantification: one is the forward propagation of uncertainty (where the various sources of uncertainty are propagated through the model to predict the overall uncertainty in the system response) and the other is the inverse assessment of model uncertainty and parameter uncertainty (where the model parameters are calibrated simultaneously using test data).

### Methodological Approaches

Existing uncertainty propagation approaches include probabilistic approaches and non-probabilistic approaches. There are basically six categories of probabilistic approaches for uncertainty propagation: Simulation-based methods including Monte Carlo simulations, importance sampling, and adaptive sampling.(no content)General surrogate-based methods involve learning a surrogate model in a non-intrusive approach in order to replace the experiment or the simulation with a cheap and fast approximation.

Web search results for query: "verification and validation"

Links: [{"title":"Verification and validation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Verification_and_validation"},{"title":"Software verification and validation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_verification_and_validation"},{"title":"Verification and validation of computer simulation models - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Verification_and_validation_of_computer_simulation_models"},{"title":"Informal methods of validation and verification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Informal_methods_of_validation_and_verification"},{"title":"Katherine Johnson Independent Verification and Validation Facility - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Katherine_Johnson_Independent_Verification_and_Validation_Facility"},{"title":"Validation and verification (medical devices) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Validation_and_verification_(medical_devices)"},{"title":"Talk:Verification and validation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Verification_and_Validation"},{"title":"Data validation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_validation"},{"title":"Process validation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Process_validation"},{"title":"Telephone number verification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Telephone_number_verification"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about verification and validation:

## Overview

Verification and validation is the process of checking that a software system meets specifications and requirements so that it fulfills its intended purpose.

## Key Differences

The two concepts serve distinct purposes:

**Verification**: Verification is intended to check that a product, service, or system meets a set of design specifications.(no content)It is the evaluation of whether or not a product, service, or system complies with a regulation, requirement, specification, or imposed condition, and it is often an internal process.

**Validation**: Validation is intended to ensure a product, service, or system results in a product, service, or system that meets the operational needs of the user.(no content)It is the assurance that a product, service, or system meets the needs of the customer and other identified stakeholders, and it often involves acceptance and suitability with external customers.

## Quick Summary

A useful way to remember the distinction: Validation can be expressed by the query "Are you building the right thing?" and verification by "Are you building it right?". "Building the right thing" refers back to the user's needs, while "building it right" checks that the specifications are correctly implemented by the system.

## Important Note

It is entirely possible that a product passes when verified but fails when validated. This can happen when, say, a product is built as per the specifications but the specifications themselves fail to address the user's needs.

Web search results for query: "patient model"

Links: [{"title":"Medical model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medical_model"},{"title":"Simulated patient - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simulated_patient"},{"title":"Patient derived xenograft - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Patient_derived_xenograft"},{"title":"E-patient - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E-patient"},{"title":"Patient-centered outcomes - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Patient-centered_outcomes"},{"title":"Patient participation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Participatory_medicine"},{"title":"Synergy model of nursing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Synergy_model_of_nursing"},{"title":"Medical simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medical_simulation"},{"title":"Medical home - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medical_home"},{"title":"Biopsychosocial model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biopsychosocial_model"}]

Based on the search results, "patient model" refers to several different concepts in healthcare depending on the context:

## Key Types of Patient Models:

**1. Simulated/Standardized Patients**
A simulated patient (SP), also known as a standardized patient, sample patient, or patient instructor, is an individual trained to act as a real patient in order to simulate a set of symptoms or problems.(no content)Simulated patients have been successfully utilized for education, evaluation of health care professionals, as well as basic, applied, and translational medical research.

**2. Patient-Derived Xenograft (PDX) Models**
Patient derived xenografts (PDX) are models of cancer where the tissue or cells from a patient's tumor are implanted into an immunodeficient or humanized mouse.(no content)PDX models are used to create an environment that allows for the continued growth of cancer after its removal from a patient. In this way, tumor growth can be monitored in the laboratory, including in response to potential therapeutic options.

**3. Medical/Healthcare Models**
In the medical model, the physician may be viewed as the dominant health care professional, who is the professional trained in diagnosis and treatment. Other related models include the biopsychosocial model, the patient-centered medical home, and participatory medicine approaches.

**4. Nursing Synergy Model**
The American Association of Critical-Care Nurses' (AACN) developed the synergy model of patient care as a conceptual framework for their critical care nurse certification program.

The specific meaning depends on whether you're referring to educational simulation, cancer research, or healthcare delivery frameworks.

Links: [{"title":"Medical model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medical_model"},{"title":"Simulated patient - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simulated_patient"},{"title":"Patient derived xenograft - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Patient_derived_xenograft"},{"title":"E-patient - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E-patient"},{"title":"Patient-centered outcomes - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Patient-centered_outcomes"},{"title":"Patient participation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Participatory_medicine"},{"title":"Synergy model of nursing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Synergy_model_of_nursing"},{"title":"Medical simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medical_simulation"},{"title":"Medical home - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medical_home"},{"title":"Biopsychosocial model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biopsychosocial_model"}]

Based on the search results, "patient model" refers to several different concepts in healthcare depending on the context:

## Key Types of Patient Models:

**1. Simulated/Standardized Patients**
A simulated patient (SP), also known as a standardized patient, sample patient, or patient instructor, is an individual trained to act as a real patient in order to simulate a set of symptoms or problems.(no content)Simulated patients have been successfully utilized for education, evaluation of health care professionals, as well as basic, applied, and translational medical research.

**2. Patient-Derived Xenograft (PDX) Models**
Patient derived xenografts (PDX) are models of cancer where the tissue or cells from a patient's tumor are implanted into an immunodeficient or humanized mouse.(no content)PDX models are used to create an environment that allows for the continued growth of cancer after its removal from a patient. In this way, tumor growth can be monitored in the laboratory, including in response to potential therapeutic options.

**3. Medical/Healthcare Models**
In the medical model, the physician may be viewed as the dominant health care professional, who is the professional trained in diagnosis and treatment. Other related models include the biopsychosocial model, the patient-centered medical home, and participatory medicine approaches.

**4. Nursing Synergy Model**
The American Association of Critical-Care Nurses' (AACN) developed the synergy model of patient care as a conceptual framework for their critical care nurse certification program.

The specific meaning depends on whether you're referring to educational simulation, cancer research, or healthcare delivery frameworks.

Web search results for query: "mathematical model validation"

Links: [{"title":"Statistical model validation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_model_validation"},{"title":"Verification and validation of computer simulation models - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Verification_and_validation_of_computer_simulation_models"},{"title":"Regression validation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regression_validation"},{"title":"Formal verification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_verification"},{"title":"Training, validation, and test data sets - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Training,_validation,_and_test_data_sets"},{"title":"Model checking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model_checking"},{"title":"Mathematical model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematical_model"},{"title":"Cross-validation (statistics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cross-validation_(statistics)"},{"title":"Simulink - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simulink"},{"title":"Model-based design - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model_based_design"}]

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of mathematical model validation:

## Definition and Purpose

Model validation is the task of evaluating whether a chosen statistical model is appropriate or not.(no content)A crucial part of the modeling process is the evaluation of whether or not a given mathematical model describes a system accurately. This question can be difficult to answer as it involves several different types of evaluation. Usually, the easiest part of model evaluation is checking whether a model predicts experimental measurements or other empirical data not used in the model development.

## Key Validation Methods

There are several approaches to validating models:

1. **Validation Sets**: Commonly, statistical models on existing data are validated using a validation set, which may also be referred to as a holdout set. A validation set is a set of data points that the user leaves out when fitting a statistical model.

2. **Residual Analysis**: Residual plots plot the difference between the actual data and the model's predictions: correlations in the residual plots may indicate a flaw in the model.

3. **Cross-Validation**: Cross validation is a method of model validation that iteratively refits the model, each time leaving out just a small sample and comparing whether the samples left out are predicted by the model: there are many kinds of cross validation.

4. **External Validation**: External validation involves fitting the model to new data.

## Important Considerations

Model validation comes in many forms and the specific method of model validation a researcher uses is often a constraint of their research design. To emphasize, what this means is that there is no one-size-fits-all method to validating a model.

Web search results for query: "medical device safety"

Links: [{"title":"Safe Medical Device Amendments of 1990 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Safe_Medical_Device_Amendments_of_1990"},{"title":"IEC 60601 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IEC_60601"},{"title":"Therac-25 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Therac-25"},{"title":"Medical device - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medical_device"},{"title":"Radiation Control for Health and Safety Act of 1968 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radiation_Control_for_Health_and_Safety_Act_of_1968"},{"title":"Postmarketing surveillance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Postmarketing_surveillance"},{"title":"Software safety classification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_safety_classification"},{"title":"Medical software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medical_software"},{"title":"ECRI Institute - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ECRI_Institute"},{"title":"Orphan device - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orphan_device"}]

I've completed a web search for "medical device safety." Here's a summary of the key findings:

## Overview of Medical Device Safety

Medical devices must be proved safe and effective with reasonable assurance before regulating governments allow marketing of the device in their country.(no content)As the associated risk of the device increases, the amount of testing required to establish safety and efficacy also increases, and as associated risk increases, the potential benefit to the patient must also increase.

## Regulatory Standards

IEC 60601 is a series of technical standards for the safety and essential performance of medical electrical equipment, published by the International Electrotechnical Commission.(no content)Compliance with IEC60601-1 has become a requirement for the commercialisation of electrical medical equipment in many countries.

## Post-Market Monitoring

Postmarketing surveillance (PMS), also known as post market surveillance, is the practice of monitoring the safety of a pharmaceutical drug or medical device after it has been released on the market and is an important part of the science of pharmacovigilance.(no content)Postmarketing surveillance is overseen by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA), which operates a system of passive surveillance called MedWatch, to which doctors or the general public can voluntarily report adverse reactions to drugs and medical devices.

## Software in Medical Devices

Software installed in medical devices is assessed for health and safety issues according to international standards, with classification based on the potential for hazard(s) that could cause injury to the user or patient.

Web search results for query: "clinical trial"

Links: [{"title":"Clinical trial - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clinical_trial"},{"title":"Phases of clinical research - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phases_of_clinical_research"},{"title":"ClinicalTrials.gov - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ClinicalTrials.gov"},{"title":"Analysis of clinical trials - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Analysis_of_clinical_trials"},{"title":"Clinical research - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clinical_research"},{"title":"Clinical study design - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clinical_study_design"},{"title":"Category:Clinical trials - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Clinical_trials"},{"title":"Pragmatic clinical trial - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pragmatic_clinical_trial"},{"title":"Society for Clinical Trials - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Society_for_Clinical_Trials"},{"title":"Glossary of clinical research - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glossary_of_clinical_research"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about clinical trials:

## Definition

Clinical trials are prospective biomedical or behavioral research studies on human participants designed to answer specific questions about biomedical or behavioral interventions, including new treatments (such as novel vaccines, drugs, dietary choices, dietary supplements, and medical devices) and known interventions that warrant further study and comparison.

## Purpose and Goals

Clinical trials generate data on dosage, safety and efficacy.(no content)There are two goals to testing medical treatments: to learn whether they work well enough, called "efficacy", or "effectiveness"; and to learn whether they are safe enough, called "safety".

## Trial Process

The sponsor designs the trial in coordination with a panel of expert clinical investigators, and during the trial, investigators recruit subjects with predetermined characteristics, administer the treatment(s) and collect data on the subjects' health for a defined time period.(no content)Clinical trials are conducted only after they have received health authority/ethics committee approval in the country where approval of the therapy is sought.

## Phases of Clinical Trials

Clinical trials testing potential medical products are commonly classified into four phases.(no content)If the drug successfully passes through Phases I, II, and III, it will usually be approved by the national regulatory authority for use in the general population. Phase IV trials are 'post-marketing' or 'surveillance' studies conducted to monitor safety over several years.

## Cost and Timeline

Costs for clinical trials can range into the billions of dollars per approved drug, and the complete trial process to approval may require 7–15 years.(no content)Only 10 percent of all drugs started in human clinical trials become approved drugs.

## Phases of Clinical Trials

Clinical trials testing potential medical products are commonly classified into four phases.(no content)If the drug successfully passes through Phases I, II, and III, it will usually be approved by the national regulatory authority for use in the general population. Phase IV trials are 'post-marketing' or 'surveillance' studies conducted to monitor safety over several years.

## Definition

Clinical trials are prospective biomedical or behavioral research studies on human participants designed to answer specific questions about biomedical or behavioral interventions, including new treatments (such as novel vaccines, drugs, dietary choices, dietary supplements, and medical devices) and known interventions that warrant further study and comparison.

Web search results for query: "in silico clinical trials"

Links: [{"title":"In silico clinical trials - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/In_silico_clinical_trials"},{"title":"In silico medicine - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/In_silico_medicine"},{"title":"In silico - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/In_silico"},{"title":"Insilico Medicine - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Insilico_Medicine"},{"title":"Talk:Insilico Medicine - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Insilico_Medicine"},{"title":"In silico (disambiguation) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/In_silico_(disambiguation)"},{"title":"Clinical trial management system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clinical_trial_management_system"},{"title":"Platform trial - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Platform_trial"},{"title":"International Clinical Trials Registry Platform - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Clinical_Trials_Registry_Platform"},{"title":"Phases of clinical research - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phase_II_clinical_trial"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about in silico clinical trials:

## Definition and Overview

An in silico clinical trial, also known as a virtual clinical trial, is an individualized computer simulation used in the development or regulatory evaluation of a medicinal product, device, or intervention.(no content)The term in silico indicates any use of computers in clinical trials, even if limited to management of clinical information in a database.

## How They Work

'Virtual' patients would be given a 'virtual' treatment, enabling observation through a computer simulation of how the candidate biomedical product performs and whether it produces the intended effect, without inducing adverse effects.

## Potential Benefits

In silico clinical trials could provide several advantages:

- Reducing the size and the duration of clinical trials through better design, for example, by identifying characteristics to determine which patients might be at greater risk of complications or providing earlier confirmation that the product or process is working as expected.

- Unlike animal models, the virtual human models can be re-used indefinitely, providing significant cost savings.

- Compared to trials in animals or a small sample of humans, in silico trials might more effectively predict the behaviour of the drug or device in large-scale trials, identifying side effects that were previously difficult or impossible to detect.

## Current Status

The development has accelerated in recent years following the growth of computer capacity and more advanced simulation models, and is now at the point that virtual platforms are gaining acceptance by regulatory bodies as a complement to conventional clinical trials for new product introductions.
